title: Treasury: £1.7 trillion ‘hole’ in public sector pension
text: 10:46 r11co said: Fair points, but they paid their contributions. If the money had not been pissed away by successive governments buying votes and instead invested in the way certain Scandinavian countries have managed to do then the problem would not have arisen. No, the contributions have always been insufficient to fund the benefits - the original intention was that the cost should broadly be split 50:50 employee:employer/taxpayer. Currently this is probably 25% employee, 75% taxpayer or worse for the more generous schemes. r11co said: Contracts were signed when they started their employment putting them on these schemes, so unless you are suggesting we just ignore contract law ? Are they still receiving the same salaries as when they signed the contracts? Have any other terms been changed?Contracts can change, just as in the private sector. r11co said: When private sector employers rob pension funds they generally end up in jail or over the side of their yacht. No-one is suggesting removing benefits accrued to date but it's ludicrous to continue allowing them to accrue further benefits on the current terms (as it has been for some time).Protect benefits accrued, revise future contributions onto defined contribution or much more appropriate adjusted defined benefit scheme.And, to be clear, the cost of the 'hole' is much more than the £1.7trillion quoted if the calculations were done on a genuine market basis. To add to that the cost of the promises for the state pension adds another few trillion... Edited by sidicks on Wednesday 21st October 10:51
